Award.AwardTitle: Extreme Virus Morphology: The Structure and Assembly of SSV1, the Prototypical Fusellovirus

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many viruses of Archaea have a spindle or lemon-like shape, which is very different from other viruses. This unique virus shape may help these viruses remain stable in the extreme environments in which they thrive. However, very little is known about the structure and assembly of spindle-shaped viruses. This project will study the structure and assembly of Sulfolobus Spindle Shaped Virus 1 (SSV1), the best-known of these so-called fuselloviruses. SSV1 replicates in extremely hot (80˚C or 176˚F) and acidic (pH = 3) conditions. The research will use cutting-edge genetic and biochemical tools pioneered in the Center for Life in Extreme Environments (CLEE) at Portland State University (PSU) and state-of-the art cryo-electron microscopy tools in collaboration with the University of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston Texas (UTMB). The major aims of the project are to determine the structure of the whole virus to ≤ 10 Ã… resolution, determine the location and kinetics of production of the major coat protein in vivo and characterize the major coat protein in vitro. Understanding the structure of SSV1 and characterizing the major coat protein in vivo and in vitro will provide insights not only into protein stability and assembly of macromolecules in extreme environments, but also virus evolution. The work also has implications for the development of nanotechnology.

Broader Impacts: Primary research will be performed in revamped teaching laboratory courses in new space. Research results will be incorporated in undergraduate lectures to at least 100 students/year. This project will directly support postdoctoral, graduate, undergraduate and high school students in CLEE at PSU and at UTMB. Many PSU students are first generation college students and underrepresented minorities. These students will be directly involved in the research in collaboration with the Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Partnerships and McNair scholarship programs. The project will also provide access for PSU students to the unique facilities at UTMB.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Viruses that infect microbes that live in high temperature acidic volcanic hot springs (temperatures around 80C, pH of 3) have markedly different structures than other viruses.  During this project, we determined the first structure of a fusellovirus, a relatively common family of viruses that are found in these ecosystems.  The structure of this virus, Sulfolobus spindle-shaped virus 1 (SSV1), was previously known to have a lemon shape with a short tail at one end.  We discovered that the tail had approximate 6-fold symmetry, with dimensions that are similar to the hexagonal S-layer that is the surface of the host cell. Thus, the tail is probably critical for attachment of the virus to the cell and infectivity.  Moreover, we proposed that the structure of the “lemon”-shaped capsid is based on so-called fullerene cone geometry that is similar to the architecture of the central part of the HIV-1 virus, and thus may provide a new paradigm for virus architecture. (See Image)  This result generated considerable local news coverage, including features in newspapers and on television.  This work was done in close collaboration between research groups at Portland State University and the University of Texas Medical Branch.

 

More recently we found that many of the genes that make up the viral genomeus are much less important than previously thought.  Surprisingly, we found that about half of the genes could be disrupted without inactivating the virus. One of the genes, which encodes a known part of the structure of the virus, the VP3 gene, could be completely deleted and the virus was still functional.  Interestingly the virus produced after this deletion has a shape that appears to be elongated relative to the normal SSV1 virus.  

 

Much of the work to make these mutants was done by students at Portland State University.  These students included two Ph.D. students, one M.S. student, over 100 undergraduate students and 6 high school students and one visiting student from France.  Many of these students are first generation college students and African-Americans, Pacific Islanders and Afghanis. An unexpected spinoff of the project was participation in the Nanoland exhibit at OMSI, including models10,000,000 times the actual life size of SSV1 viruses.  This exhibit had thousands of visitors.
